thread.title: Graphic: Barca star’s horror injury by own keeper
thread.title_full: Graphic: Barca star’s horror injury by own keeper

title: Graphic: Barca star’s horror injury by own keeper
text:
Messi bags free kick record 0:38 Paper Talk: Barca star’s graphic broken nose, Neymar and Ronaldo comparison February 6, 2017 4:23pm by Staff writers with AFP Source: FOX SPORTS A Barcelona star’s graphic broken nose, what it’s like for Lionel Messi to leave the Nou Camp, and an incredible Neymar and Ronaldo comparison. 
All that and more in Monday Paper Talk! 
BARCA’S RAFINHA SUFFERS BROKEN NOSE 
Barcelona midfielder Rafinha faces a spell on the sidelines after suffering a broken nose in a clash with his own goalkeeper Marc-Andre ter Stegen in Saturday’s 3-0 win over Athletic Bilbao. 
Barca refused to confirm on Sunday how long the Brazilian would be out for but he seems certain to miss Tuesday’s Copa del Rey semi-final second leg at home to Atletico Madrid, with Barcelona holding a 2-1 aggregate lead. 
The Spanish champions face a congested fixture list over the next six weeks with seven La Liga matches and a Champions League blockbuster last-16 tie against Paris Saint-Germain. 
However, Barca could be handed a big injury boost ahead of Atletico’s visit to the Camp Nou in midweek with Spanish international duo Andres Iniesta and Sergio Busquets close to a return. Rafinha. Source: Supplied Ter Stegen catches Rafinha on the head. Source: FOX SPORTS The blood drips for Rafinha’s face. Source: FOX SPORTS 
WHAT IT’S LIKE FOR MESSI TO LEAVE THE NOU CAMP 
Lionel Messi starred for Barca again with a free kick in the win over Bilbao, which made him the club’s all-time record holder for free kick goals with 27. The previous holder was Ronald Koeman. 
After the game, Messi left the Nou Camp with his fiance Antonella Roccuzzo. She gave the world a taste of what it’s like for the Argentine to be swarmed by fans when departing the stadium. 
Check out the video she uploaded to Instagram stories. This is what it's like for Leo Messi to leave the Camp Nou!Video via Antonella Rocuzzo on Instagram. pic.twitter.com/VLtYa7VUt8 — 101 Great Goals (@101greatgoals) February 4, 2017 
INCREDIBLE NEYMAR AND RONALDO COMPARISON 
Brazil legend Pele recently declared that Neymar is “way better” than Cristiano Ronaldo, and it turns that statement may have some truth to it. 
Neymar, 25, has almost double the amount of goals that the Portuguese had at the same age. 
However, the Barcelona star scored over 50 goals for Santos in Brazil, while Ronaldo launched his career playing far fewer games and against tougher opposition at Manchester United. 
Neymar has an average of 0.56 goals per game since moving to the La Liga giant, but Ronaldo has scored at a rate of 0.98 goals per game in the seven years since his 25th birthday. 
For comparison, Messi had 279 goals by his 25th birthday. Neymar vs Ronaldo at the age of 25.. pic.twitter.com/KyLqGdYpic — Leo Messi (@messi10stats) February 6, 2017 
RONALDO CELEBRATES 32ND BIRTHDAY 
Real Madrid’s postponed match against Celta Vigo this weekend gave Ronaldo the opportunity to celebrate his 32nd birthday with his mother and son. 
His mother posted a picture of herself, Ronaldo and Cristiano Jr behind a big birthday cake on her Instagram account. A photo posted by @doloresaveiroofficial on Feb 5, 2017 at 5:59am PST 
WOMEN AND CHILDREN ATTACKED IN DORTMUND FAN CLASH 
Borussia Dortmund have threatened to ban any fans responsible for the violent attacks on RB Leipzig supporters, including children and women, that led to 28 arrests before a Bundesliga match. 
“We can assure you: Borussia Dortmund will do its utmost to clear up our own fans’ misconduct and sanction them as hard as possible,” Dortmund’s CEO Hans-Joachim Watzke and president Reinhard Rauball wrote in an open letter. 
“To put it plainly, anyone who expresses his opinion not by arguments, but by raw violence and clumsy insults, can not -- and will not -- be allowed to be part of this club.” Dortmund can also expect to face tough sanctions with the German Football Association (DFB) set to investigate the violence. 
A crowd of 81,360 saw Dortmund’s 1-0 home win over second-placed RB Leipzig on Saturday, but there were ugly scenes outside Borussia’s Signal Iduna Park stadium before kick-off when some of the 8,500 visiting fans were targeted. Dortmund's supporters on the southern tribune. Source: AP 
“In the build-up to the match, in the Strobelallee area (outside the ground), RB Leipzig supporters were bombarded with stones and cans from Borussia Dortmund fans,” police said in a statement. 
RB Leipzig were unable to tell SID, an AFP subsidiary, how many of their fans were hurt, but German daily Bild claimed at least 10 visiting supporters were hospitalised. 
After a group of around 500 hardcore ‘Ultra’ Dortmund fans went on the rampage, police weighed in with pepper spray and batons. 
Arrests were made for offences including assault, grievous bodily harm, breach of the peace, insulting behaviour and resisting arrest. 
“All in all, there was extreme aggressiveness and violence from Dortmund supporters, which was directed against any person recognised as a Leipzig fan, regardless of whether they were small children, women or families,” added Dortmund police. 
“In connection with this, four officers and a police dog were injured.” Leizpig, who are in their first season in Germany’s top flight, slammed the attacks as “unacceptable”. View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
